[[File:Photosensitive glass vase.jpg|thumb|<center>Photosensitive glass vase]] '''Photosensitive glass''', also known as photostructurable glass (PSG), or photomachinable glass, is a crystal-clear [[glass]] that belongs to the lithium-silicate family of glasses, in which an image of a mask {{clarify|date=March 2014}} can be captured by microscopic metallic particles in the glass when it is exposed to short wave radiations such as ultraviolet light.<ref name = "glass fab1">{{cite journal | doi = 10.1016/0167-9317(95)00295-2 | volume=30 | title=Fabrication technologies for microsystems utilizing photoetchable glass | journal=Microelectronic Engineering | pages=497–504| year=1996 | last1=Dietrich | first1=T.R | last2=Ehrfeld | first2=W | last3=Lacher | first3=M | last4=Krämer | first4=M | last5=Speit | first5=B }}</ref> Photosensitive glass was first discovered by [[S. Donald Stookey]] in 1937.<ref name ="stookey1">Paul, p. 333</ref><ref name ="june1">Encyclopædia Britannica, pp. 194–209</ref><ref name ="glassfacts1">Maluf, pp. 62–63</ref>
==History== Photosensitive glass was invented in November 1937 by [[S. Donald Stookey|Dr. Donald Stookey]] of the [[Corning Glass Works]].<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name ="june1"/> It was not announced publicly until ten years later on June 1, 1947.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name ="june1"/> It was officially patented in 1950 by Stookey as U.S. Pat. No. 2,515,937 and U.S. Pat. Nos. 2,515,943 with gold microscopic particles<ref name ="stookey1"/> and marketed under the trade name PhotoCor(R).
==Exposure process== When the glass is exposed to UV light in the wavelength range 280–320 nm, a [[latent image]] is formed. The glass remains transparent at this stage, but its absorption in the uv range of the spectrum increases. This increased absorption is only detectable using uv transmission spectroscopy.<ref name = "glass fab2">{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/khalidtantawi/photosensitive-glass|title=Photodefinable Glass Processing - khalidtantawi|website=sites.google.com}}</ref> The reason behind this is suggested to be an [[oxidation reduction reaction]] that occurs inside the glass during exposure in which cerium ions are oxidized to a more stable state and silver ions are reduced to silver.<ref name = "glass fab2"/>
==Post-exposure heat treatment== When the glass is heated to temperatures in the range 550–560 °C<ref name = "glass fab3">{{cite web|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/0960-1317/21/1/017001/refs|title=Processing of photosensitive APEX glass structures with smooth and transparent sidewalls by Khalid H Tantawi, Janeczka Oates, Reza Kamali, Nathan Bergquist and John D Williams, Journal of Micromech. & Microeng. 21 (2011)|publisher=}}</ref> for several hours the latent image is converted to a visible image through photoexcitation.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name ="glassfacts1"/> Exposure through photographic negatives permits the development of three-dimensional color images and photographs.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name ="glassfacts1"/> This heat treatment is done in two stages: the temperature is first raised to about 500 °C to allow for the completion of the oxidation-reduction reaction, and formation of silver nanoclusters. In the following stage, when the temperature is raised to 550–560 °C, a new material (lithium metasilicate) with the formula (Li<sub>2</sub>SiO<sub>3</sub>) forms on the silver nanoclustors, this material forms in the crystalline phase.<ref name = "glass fab3"/>
==HF chemical etching== The lithium metasilicate that forms in the exposed regions of the glass has the unique property of being strongly etched in [[Hydrofluoric Acid|hydrofluoric acid (HF)]]. Hence allowing a three-dimensional image of the mask to be produced, the resulting glass microstructures have a surface roughness in the range 5 μm<ref name = "glass fab1"/> to 0.7 μm.<ref name = "glass fab3"/>
== X-ray sensitive glasses == As stated above radiation produces some direct and indirect measurable changes in the glasses. In some cases, the effect is readily observable immediately upon irradiation. In other cases, thermal treatment is required to bring about the observed changes. On the whole, the result of the mentioned reactions will be atomic silvers and/or silver clusters which act as nucleant for precipitation of lithium-meta-silicate during post heat-treatment of irradiated glass and Similar to other glass-ceramic systems, the more nucleation sites leads to more reduction of crystallization temperature and finer crystalline size. Therefore, to attain the above-mentioned condition, various energetic radiation such as UVand laser beam and x γ and proton and radiations have been used for different photosensitive glasses until now. [https://sites.google.com/site/samimanieh/home Imanieh] et al.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Imanieh|first=M.H. |author2=Eftekhari Yekta, B. |author3=Marghussian, V. |author4=Aghaei, A. |title=Effect of X-ray irradiation on solarization and crystallization of photosensitive glasses containing Ce, Sb, Sn and Ag|journal=Journal of Non-Crystalline Solids|date=August 2008|volume=354|issue=31|pages=3752–3755|doi=10.1016/j.jnoncrysol.2008.04.007}}</ref> investigated the effect of X-ray irradiation on solarization of photosensitive lithium silicate based glasses containing cerium, antimony, tin and silver elements. They have shown that there is a possibility to use X-ray in photosensitive glasses. This will open new doors for nano machining of glasses in near future.
==Applications== [[File:Photosensitive glass.jpg|thumb|<center> Photosensitive glass]] [[File:'spinifex' photosensitive glass.jpg|thumb|<center> Spinfex photosensitive glass]] Photosensitive glass is used in printing and reproducing processes.<ref name=" photosensitive1">{{cite web |url= http://www.gafferglass.com/technical/photosensitive_main.htm |title= Photosensitive Glasses |accessdate= 2008-08-15 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080828041509/http://www.gafferglass.com/technical/photosensitive_main.htm |archivedate= 2008-08-28 |df= }}</ref> Photosensitive glass is like traditional camera film except that it reacts to ultraviolet (UV) light, where camera film responds to visible light.<ref name ="glassfacts1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill">Parker, 2003</ref> The ideal wavelength to use for exposure should be between 300 and 350 nm, with 320 nm being optimum.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/>
Photosensitive glass contains microscopic metallic particles.<ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> These microscopic metallic ion nanoparticles are made of gold or silver which is responsible for the refractive index change.<ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> Photosensitive glass is similar to photographic film. Photographic film uses chemicals, while photosensitive glass uses gold or silver ions in the material that will respond to the action of light.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/> The process is to pass light of the ultraviolet wavelength through a negative on the glass.<ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> Photographic resolution can be obtained with adhesive polyester as a reverse negative, however anything which resists UV light can act as a "negative."<ref name =" photosensitive1"/>
The glass is sensitive to light that when passes through a mask can ultimately turn it into a permanent picture with a heat process "fixing" permanently the image.<ref name ="glassfacts1"/><ref name =" photosensitive1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> Silver glass "latent images" will develop in 3–4 hours at 886–976 °F.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/> Gold glass "latent images" require a higher temperature of 968–1058 °F and over a similar period of time for postbaking.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/> Postbaking hastens the occurrence of the particles with the shadow areas of the negative, permitting deeper penetration into the glass than the highlighted areas.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> This gives the picture three dimensions and color.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/>
The photograph is developed by heating the photosensitive glass around 1000 °F for several hours after exposure.<ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> The glass itself is photosensitive and produces a three-dimensional image.<ref name ="stookey1"/> Particles that are invisible to the naked eye (i.e. gold or silver) are in the glass. These microscopic particles move and grow when heated to form the photographic image itself.<ref name ="stookey1"/> The process is similar to camera film, however a "negative" is placed on top of the photosensitive glass and then exposed to ‘’’ultraviolet’’’ light. Camera film, of course, would be exposed to ordinary visible light. Then there is a special process for the exposed photosensitive glass. The glass is reheated then in a [[kiln]] and postbaked for several hours. The image then "appears" within the special exposed glass as if by magic. The heated piece of photosensitive glass is then allowed to cool down and the process is done. The positive images produced within photosensitive glass comes in a variety of colors.
As a material for the hot glass studio artist, an additional method of producing imagery in an object using photosensitive glass is to first blow an extremely thin rondel (cased or otherwise) which is annealed in the typical manner. That rondel is then cut into sections which are exposed under a negative. Next, those sections (containing the latent image) are warmed and applied to the surface of a gather of hot glass on the blowpipe. As the object is completed over several furnace reheats, the heat develops the image as the object is being created. This method specifically eliminates the need for the reheating of the object in a kiln for development, which consumes considerable oven time, energy, and the risk of loss or damage due to shattering on the way up to temperature, or more importantly, slumping while being held at temperature. The timing of the glassblower determines the final degree of development, and simple choices of form minimize distortion in the image.
Since the image is inside and actually a part of the glass itself, photosensitive glass is the most durable photographic medium known.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> It is claimed that a photo image within photosensitive glass is the most durable form of photography and will last as long as the glass itself.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name ="june1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/> The photographic image is '''not''' on the surface of the glass, but internally.<ref name ="stookey1"/>
Fluorescent photosensitive glass makes it possible to make fluorescent photographs and fluorescence holography.<ref name ="fluorescent1">{{cite journal|url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science?_ob=ArticleURL&_udi=B6WM2-45S99G6-48&_user=10&_rdoc=1&_fmt=&_orig=search&_sort=d&view=c&_version=1&_urlVersion=0&_userid=10&md5=61111fe4a495093bf3b6946e0ef0ca18|title= Fluorescent Photosensitive Glass—A Novel Material for Optical Memory and Fluorescence Holography |accessdate= 2008-08-15|doi=10.1006/jssc.1997.7580|volume=134|issue= 2 |journal=Journal of Solid State Chemistry|pages=362–363|year= 1997 |last1= Pavel |first1= E |last2= Tugulea |first2= L }}</ref>
Photosensitive glass is different from [[Photochromism|photochromatic glass]].<ref name ="glassfacts1"/> Photochromatic glass is used in self-darkening sunglasses which darkens when exposed to bright daylight.<ref name ="glassfacts1"/> It then returns to see-through transparency when strong daylight is removed and can then be used indoors as regular glasses.<ref name ="glassfacts1"/>
Little has been done to develop the product since its patent.<ref name ="stookey1"/> It is labor-intensive and has a high cost.<ref name ="stookey1"/> Only large commercial glass factories produce it.<ref name ="stookey1"/> In the 1980s photosensitive glass was created to a small degree to be used in "hot glass" work.<ref name ="stookey1"/> Then individual artists owned smaller studios and created works in blown glass and began experimenting with photosensitive glass.<ref name ="stookey1"/> Going into the Twenty-First Century only a few glass artists know the technique of achieving good results with photosensitive glass.<ref name ="stookey1"/> In the present time, the only photosensitive glasses produced are PhotoCor(R), [[Foturan]] and APEX. [http://flatpaneldisplay.blogspot.com/2018/09/cornings-secret-menu.html PhotoCor] is produced by the inventor, Corning, Inc. [[Foturan]] is produced by [[Schott AG|SCHOTT Corporation]] and APEX by Life Bioscience.<ref name ="glass fab2"/> Photosensitive glass has been used as a holographic material to record diffractive optical elements for high power laser applications.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Glebov |first=Leonid B. |title=Photosensitive holographic glass - new approach to creation of high power lasers |journal=Physics and Chemistry of Glasses: European Journal of Glass Science and Technology Part B |volume=48 |date=June 2007 |pages=123–128}}</ref>
===Military applications=== One of the reasons for the delay between the invention of photosensitive glass and its public announcement approximately ten years later was its potential use in military applications.<ref name =" photosensitive1"/> It is possible to burn images and words that are hidden in photosensitive glass until heated at a high temperature.<ref name ="stookey1"/> The military used this fact during World War II to send secret messages to allied troops in pieces of what looked like "ordinary glass".<ref name ="stookey1"/> At the other hand, the person who received the "ordinary glass" just had to heat it up to read the hidden message.<ref name ="stookey1"/> Because of this application photosensitive glass was kept secret until the end of World War II.<ref name ="stookey1"/><ref name = "McGraw-Hill"/>
===Building applications=== The [[United Nations Building]] is faced with hundreds of square feet of photosensitive glass.<ref name ="henrys1">{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/?id=EPIuXHxLJRgC&pg=PA344&dq=photosensitive+glass|title=Henry's Attic By Ford Richardson Bryan et al., p. 344 |accessdate= 2008-08-19|isbn=978-0814326428 |last1=Bryan |first1=Ford Richardson |year=1995 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Photochromic lens]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
===Bibliography=== * Encyclopædia Britannica, ''The New Encyclopædia Britannica'', v.8 Macropaedia Ge-Hu, Encyclopædia Britannica, 1974, {{ISBN|0-85229-290-2}} * Parker, Sybil P., ''Dictionary of Scientific and Technical Terms.'' McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc., (2003) - "photosensitive glass," {{ISBN|0-07-042313-X}}, * Maluf, Nadim et al., ''Introduction to Microelectromechanical Systems Engineering'', Artech House, 2004, {{ISBN|1-58053-590-9}} * Paul, Amal, ''Chemistry of Glasses'', Springer, 1990, {{ISBN|0-412-27820-0}} * Stookey, S. Donald, ''Journey to the Center of the Crystal Ball : An Autobiography'', American Ceramic Society (1985), {{ISBN|0-916094-69-3}} * Stookey, S. Donald, ''Explorations in Glass: An Autobiography'', Wiley-Blackwell (2000), {{ISBN|1-57498-124-2}}
==External links== {{Glass science}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2013}}
{{infobox software
|title=Proto.io |developer= Labs Division of SNQ Digital |released= 2011 |latest release date= September 2012 |website= http://proto.io
}}
'''Proto.io''' is an [[mobile application|application]] prototyping platform launched in 2011 and developed by the Labs Division of SNQ Digital.<ref name="CB">{{cite web |url=http://www.crunchbase.com/company/proto-io |title=Proto.io |author= |date=27 July 2012 |publisher=CrunchBase |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="UX">{{cite web |url=http://uxmag.com/resources/protoio-mobile-prototyping |title=Proto.io - Mobile Prototyping |author=Artemis Pattichi |date= |publisher=UX Magazine |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="MS">{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2012/06/07/mockup-tools/ |title=9 Excellent Tools for Design Mockups |author=Kelli Shaver |date=7 June 2012 |publisher=Mashable |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> Originally designed to prototype on mobile devices, Proto.io has expanded to allow users to prototype apps for anything with a screen interface, including [[smart TV|Smart TV’s]], [[digital camera]] interfaces, [[cars]], [[airplanes]], and [[gaming consoles]]. Proto.io utilizes a drag and drop user interface (UI) and does not require [[computer programming|coding]].<ref name="CB" /><ref name="UX" /><ref name="NE">{{cite web |url=http://www.netmagazine.com/features/20-best-new-tools-web-design-and-development-2012 |title=Mark Penfold Compiles a Top 20 From His Monthly Roundup of the Best New Tools That Saw the Light of Day This Year - and Many are Free! |author=Mark Penfold |date=12 December 2012 |publisher= |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
==History==
Since its launch in 2011, there have been three versions of Proto.io released.
===Version 1=== In 2011, SNQ made the 100% web-based Proto.io tool available online.<ref name="CB" /><ref name="UX" /> The web-based environment allowed users to create a project for either the [[iPad]] or [[iPhone]]. After a user created a few screens for a developing app, Proto.io could then link those pages together with interactive actions that are custom to hand held devices, such as clicks, taps, tap and holds, and swipes.<ref name="WF1">{{cite web |url=http://wireframes.linowski.ca/2011/10/proto-io-mobile-app-prototyping/ |title=Proto.io - Mobile App Prototyping |author=Alexis Piperides |date=13 October 2011 |publisher=Wireframes |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="AE">{{cite web |url=http://www.aericon.com/blog/mobile-blog/fast-mobile-prototyping-with-proto-io/ |title=Fast Mobile Prototyping with Proto.io |author=Dean Whitney |date=28 November 2012 |publisher=AerIcon |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref><ref name="DJ">{{cite web |url=http://digitaljournal.com/blog/19829#tab=comments&sc=0 |title=Why Proto.io is a Revolution in Prototyping |author=Hayder Rehman |date=31 December 2012 |publisher=Digital Journal |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> With the platform, users could also create reusable templates into which prepackaged and editable elements could be dragged. Once the user had completed the prototype, Proto.io could then publish and preview the finished product not only on the web browser but also on the actual mobile device.<ref name="WF1" />
===Version 2===
Proto.io V2 was released in early 2012 and expanded the supported mobile devices to accommodate for the Android platform, to include the Android Smartphone and Tablet. The platform also came with a newer user interface. Proto.io V2 also added collaboration features like comments and annotations as well as export to [[HTML]] functionality.<ref name="WF2">{{cite web |url=http://wireframes.linowski.ca/2012/03/proto-io-v2-silly-fast-mobile-prototyping/ |title=Proto.io V2 - Silly-fast Mobile Prototyping |author= |date=15 March 2012 |publisher=Wireframes |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref>
===Version 3===
On September 28, 2012, with the release of version 3 of the platform, Proto.io became the first prototyping tool to allow users to prototype on almost any device with a screen interface, and the first mobile prototyping tool to support full feature animations of user interface items within a prototype screen.<ref name="WF3">{{cite web |url=http://wireframes.linowski.ca/2012/10/proto-io-v3-changes-mobile-prototyping-as-we-know-it/ |title=Proto.io V3 - Changes Mobile Prototyping As We Know It |author=Alexis Piperides |date=1 October 2012 |publisher=Wireframes |accessdate=4 January 2013}}</ref> The included icon gallery contains thousands of SVG icons for use as buttons, lists and tab bars.<ref name="DJ" /> Proto.io V3 also supports web fonts, which allows the user to access all available online fonts.<ref name="WF3" />
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2011}}
A '''recuperative multi-tube cooler''' is a rotary drum cooler used for continuous processes in [[chemical engineering]].
== Construction == Recuperative multi-tube coolers essentially exist of a turning rotor which is mostly driven via chain. At the ends of the rotor are stiff cases for product feed and outlet. The rotor is supported on running treads, as it is typical for rotary drums. The interior of the rotor exists of several tubes in a revolvertype (or planetary) arrangement. The tubes are completely surrounded by a jacket.
According to requirements recuperative multi-tube coolers are built with diameters between 1.0 and 4.0 m and lengths from 10 to 40 m.
== Function == Recuperative multi-tube coolers work with indirect air cooling. That means, that there is no direct contact between the product to be cooled and the cooling air. The heat is exchanged indirectly via thermal conduction. Ambient air is used as cooling air, which is drawn between the jacket and the tubes. Product and cooling air pass through the cooler in counterflow. The product to be cooled falls directly into the product feed housing. By the rotary movement and a little slope of the rotor, the product is conveyed through the cooler. The rotation causes a permanent mixing of the product in the tubes and hence a good heat transfer.
Due to the indirect method of operation, the coolers provide hot and clean air that can be reused as energy. This opportunity of recovering energy is where the term recuperative results from.
== Applications == The coolers can be used for the cooling of free flowing, fine grained bulk material. They are especially used when consumers of the recovered hot air are close-by. Usual this is the case in [[calcination]] processes after hotgas fired [[rotary kiln]]s in or similar. The hot air is used as preheated supply of combustion air in the kilns. The consumption of primary energy can be reduced seriously.
The coolers are mostly used in the pigment industry, e.g. for cooling of titandioxide pigments after calcination. The entry temperatures of the products can reach up to 1000 °C.
== External links == * [http://www.grenzebach.com/index.php/eng/produkthauptordner/verfahrenstechnik/thermische_verfahrenstechnik/rekuperativ_roehrenkuehler Pictures and explanations]
[[Category:Heat exchangers]] [[Category:Cooling technology]]

page.title: Regulation of UAVs in the United States

revision.comment: added Harvard cite; added court cite
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{update|date=May 2017}} The US [[Federal Aviation Administration]] has adopted the name ''unmanned aircraft'' (UA) to describe [[unmanned aerial vehicle|aircraft systems without a flight crew on board]].<ref name="FAA summary" /> More common names include ''UAV'', ''drone'', ''remotely piloted vehicle'' (''RPV''), ''remotely piloted aircraft'' (''RPA''), and ''remotely operated aircraft'' (''ROA''). These "limited-size" (as defined by the ''[[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]]'') unmanned aircraft flown in the USA's [[National Airspace System]], flown solely for recreation and sport purposes, such as models, are generally{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} flown under the voluntary safety standards of the [[Academy of Model Aeronautics]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.modelaircraft.org/files/105.pdf |title=Model "Academy of Model Aeronautics National Model Aircraft Safety Code" |date=January 1, 2014}}</ref> the United States' national aeromodeling organization. To operate a UA for non-recreational purposes in the United States, according to the FAA users must obtain a ''Certificate of Authorization'' (COA) to operate in national airspace.<ref name="FAA: Certificate of Authorization or Waiver (COA)">{{cite web|title=FAA: Certificate of Authorization or Waiver (COA)|url=http://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/ato/service_units/systemops/aaim/organizations/uas/coa/}}</ref> In December 2015 the FAA announced that all UAVs weighing more than 250 grams flown for any purpose must be registered with the FAA.<ref name ="Drone Registration">{{cite news| url=http://www.inc.com/joseph-steinberg/drones-in-america-must-now-be-registered-here-is-what-you-need-to-know.html |work=Inc. | title=Drones in America Must Now Be Registered. Here's What You Need to Know | date=December 16, 2015 | accessdate=December 16, 2015 |author=Joseph Steinberg |authorlink=Joseph Steinberg}}</ref>
== Regulation == The [[FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CRPT-112hrpt381/pdf/CRPT-112hrpt381.pdf|format=PDF|title=FAA MODERNIZATION AND REFORM ACT OF 2012 |publisher=Gpo.gov|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref> sets a deadline of September 30, 2015, for the agency to establish regulations to allow the use of commercial drones. In the meantime, the agency claims it is illegal to operate commercial unmanned aerial vehicles, but approves non-commercial flights under 400 feet if they follow [[AC 91-57|Advisory Circular 91-57]], Model Aircraft Operating Standards, published in 1981.<ref name="FAA summary">{{cite web|url=http://www.faa.gov/about/initiatives/uas/reg/media/frnotice_uas.pdf |accessdate=March 14, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610135230/http://www.faa.gov/about/initiatives/uas/reg/media/frnotice_uas.pdf |archivedate=June 10, 2014 }}</ref> However, the FAA's attempt to fine a commercial drone operator for a 2011 flight were thrown out on March 6, 2014 by NTSB judge Patrick Geraghty, who found that the FAA had not followed the proper rulemaking procedures and therefore had no UAV regulations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/03/faa-small-drones-ban-104393.html |title=Judge strikes down small drones ban |last1=Robillard |first1=Kevin |date=March 6, 2014 |website=www.politico.com |publisher=Politico LLC |accessdate=March 6, 2014}}</ref> The FAA will appeal the judgment.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/03/07/us-usa-aircraft-drones-idUSBREA261PY20140307 |title=U.S. FAA will appeal ruling on commercial drone use |last1=Krasny |first1=Ros |last2=Maler |first2=Sandra |date=March 7, 2014 |website=www.reuters.com |publisher=Thomson Reuters |accessdate=March 7, 2014}}</ref> Texas EquuSearch, which performs volunteer [[search and rescue]] operations, was also challenging FAA rules in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://amablog.modelaircraft.org/amagov/2014/04/21/texas-equusearch-requests-faa-to-reverse-its-ban-on-uas-search-rescue-operations/|title=Texas EquuSearch petitions the court to reverse FAA's ban on volunteer UAS Search & Rescue operations - AMA Government Relations Blog|publisher=Amablog.modelaircraft.org|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref>
As of August 2013, commercial unmanned aerial system<ref>Ahlers, Mike. November 7, 2013. [http://cnn.com-news.info/t1cn FAA takes initial steps to introduce private drones in U.S. skies] CNN. Retrieved December 3, 2013.</ref> (UAS) licenses were granted on a case-by-case basis, subject to approval by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). Previously, COAs required a public entity as a sponsor. For example, when BP needed to observe oil spills, they operated the [[Aeryon Scout]] UAVs under a COA granted to the University of Alaska Fairbanks.<ref name="Unmanned aircraft to assist oil spill response">{{cite web|title=Unmanned aircraft to assist oil spill response|url=http://www.aeryon.com/news/pressreleases/256-uafbpjuly2011.html}}</ref> COAs have been granted for both land and shipborne operations.<ref name="Shipborne CoA">{{cite web|title=Aeryon Scout™ Micro-UAV Provides Aerial Perspective for Ship-Based Wildlife Research Project in Bering Sea|url=http://www.aeryon.com/news/pressreleases/347-aeryon-scout-sealions-2012.html}}</ref> In 2014, the FAA approved at least ten applications from specific companies for commercial use of drones, including movie-makers and surveyors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/12/10/faa-drones-trimble-vdos-clayco-woolpert-amazon/20187761/|title=FAA lets 4 companies fly commercial drones|author=Bart Jansen, USA TODAY|date=December 10, 2014|publisher=Usatoday.com|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/09/25/faa-drones-movie-making/16164439/|title=FAA approves drones for moviemaking|author=Bart Jansen, USA TODAY|date=September 25, 2014|publisher=Usatoday.com|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref>
In December 2013, the FAA announced six operators it was authorizing to conduct research on drone technology, to inform its pending regulations and future developments. These were the [[University of Alaska]] (including locations in Hawaii and Oregon), the state of [[Nevada]], [[Griffiss International Airport]] in New York State, the [[North Dakota Department of Commerce]], [[Texas A&M University–Corpus Christi]], and [[Virginia Tech]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faa.gov/news/updates/?newsId=75399|title=FAA Selects Six Sites for Unmanned Aircraft Research|publisher=Taa.gov|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref>
In addition to FAA certification, the regulation of usage of UA systems by government authorities in the United States for law enforcement purposes is determined at a state level. As of September 2014, 20 U.S. states had enacted legislation addressing the use of UA systems and the handling of data collected by them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/civil-and-criminal-justice/current-uas-state-law-landscape.aspx|title=Current Unmanned Aircraft State Law Landscape|publisher=Ncsl.org|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref> Nearly all enacted laws require a probable cause warrant to be issued before the use of a UA system for surveillance purposes is authorized.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/blog/technology-and-liberty/status-2014-domestic-drone-legislation-states|title=Status of 2014 Domestic Drone Legislation in the States|work=American Civil Liberties Union|accessdate=January 8, 2015}}</ref>
In May 2014, a group of major news media companies filed an ''[[Amicus curiae|amicus]]'' brief in a case before the U.S.'s [[National Transportation Safety Board]], asserting that the [[Federal Aviation Administration|FAA]]'s "overly broad" administrative limitations against private UAS operations cause an "impermissible chilling effect on the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] newsgathering rights of journalists", the brief being filed three months before a scheduled rollout of FAA commercial operator regulations.<ref name=WashPost20140507>{{cite news|last=Fung|first=Brian|title=Major news outlets call the FAA’s drone restrictions a violation of the First Amendment|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2014/05/07/major-news-outlets-call-the-faas-drone-restrictions-a-violation-of-the-first-amendment/?wprss=rss_technology|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 7, 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PQ8zvSdm?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2014/05/07/major-news-outlets-call-the-faas-drone-restrictions-a-violation-of-the-first-amendment/?wprss=rss_technology|archivedate=May 8, 2014|deadurl=no|df=mdy-all}} ''FAA v. Pirker'' brief is posted [http://www.hklaw.com/files/Uploads/Documents/CaseBriefs/MediaLaw/Drones.pdf here].</ref>
The FAA is required by [[United States Congress|Congress]] to come up with rules for commercial use of drones by 2015.<ref name="DronesMovies">{{cite news|title=Seven movie makers seek permission to use drone for shooting |url=http://www.losangelesherald.com/index.php/sid/222543459/scat/3a8a80d6f705f8cc/ht/Seven-movie-makers-seek-permission-to-use-drone-for-shooting|accessdate=4 June 2014|publisher=''Los Angeles Herald''}}</ref>
On January 12, 2015, [[CNN]] announced that their News Network has been cleared by the FAA, in the first program of its kind to test camera-equipped drones for news gathering and reporting purposes. CNN has partnered with the Georgia Tech Research Institute to collect data for the program. The FAA said it will analyze the information to develop rules about using drones for news gathering.<ref name="CNN Cleared By FAA To Test Drones For News Reporting">{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2015/01/12/technology/cnn-drone/|title=CNN cleared to test drones for reporting|accessdate=January 12, 2015|work=CNN Money}}</ref>
On February 15, 2015, The FAA announced that up to seven thousand businesses could get approval to fly drones two years from now under proposed rules by the FAA. On Sunday the White House also issued a presidential directive that mandates federal agencies for the first time to disclose publicly where they are flying drones and what they do with the data they acquire using aerial surveillance.
In December 2015 the FAA announced that all UAVs weighing more than 250 grams flown for any purpose must be registered with the FAA.<ref name="Drone Registration"/> The FAA's Interim Rule can be [https://www.faa.gov/news/updates/media/20151213_IFR.pdf accessed here]. This regulation went into effect on December 21, 2015 and requires that hobby type UAV's between 250 grams and 55 pounds need to be registered no later than February 19, 2016.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Thomas E.|title=That Drone in Your Holiday Stocking Must Now Be Registered With FAA|date=17 December 2015|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/drone-your-holiday-stocking-must-now-be-registered-faa|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=Neal, Gerber & Eisenberg LLP}}</ref> The FAA's registration portal for drones can be [https://www.faa.gov/uas/registration/ accessed here].
Notable requirements of the FAA UAV registration process include: * Effective December 21, 2015, if the UAV has never been operated in U.S. airspace (i.e. its first flight outside), eligible owners must register their UAV's prior to flight. If the UAV previously operated in U.S. airspace, it must be registered by February 19, 2016. * In order to use the registration portal, you must be 13 years of age or older. If the owner is less than 13 years old, then a parent or other responsible person must do the FAA registration. * Each registrant will receive a certificate of aircraft registration and a registration number and all UAV's must be marked with the FAA issued registration number.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ritt|first1=Steven L.|title=Drones: Recreational/Hobby Owners Web-based Registration Process|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/drones-recreationalhobby-owners-web-based-registration-process|accessdate=17 December 2015|work=The National Law Review|publisher=Michael Best & Friedrich LLP|date=15 December 2015}}</ref> * The FAA registration requires a $5 fee, though the FAA is waiving the fee for the first 30 days of the new registration period - until January 20, 2016. The registration is good for 3 years, but can be renewed for an additional 3 years at the $5 rate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Brian D|last2=Schenendorf|first2=Jack L|last3=Kiehl|first3=Stephen|title=Looking Forward After the FAA’s Drone Registration Regulation|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/looking-forward-after-faa-s-drone-registration-regulation|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=Covington & Burling LLP|date=16 December 2015}}</ref>
The new FAA rule provides that a single registration applies to as many UAVs as an owner/operator owns or operates. Failure to register can result in civil penalties of up to $27,500 and criminal penalties which could include fines up to $250,000 and/or imprisonment for up to three years.<ref name="That Drone">{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Thomas E.|title=That Drone in Your Holiday Stocking Must Now Be Registered With FAA|journal=The National Law Review|date=17 December 2015|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/drone-your-holiday-stocking-must-now-be-registered-faa|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=Neal, Gerber & Eisenberg LLP}}</ref>
To show problems with the FAA process, in August, 2015 an attorney was able to get FAA approval for a commercial drone that was actually a battery powered paper airplane toy. Its controllable range is 120 feet (37 meters) and maximum flight time is 10 minutes. It is too underpowered to carry a camera.<ref>[http://www.aopa.org/News-and-Video/All-News/2015/September/02/Lawyer-gets-FAA-to-approve-paper-airplane Lawyer gets FAA to approve paper airplane]</ref>
In February 2016, the FAA established a committee to develop [http://www.topdronesforsale.org/drones-guidelines-by-federal-aviation-administration/ guidelines for regulating safe UAV flight] over populated areas,<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=20015 | title = Press Release – FAA Unveils Effort to Expand the Safe Integration of Unmanned Aircraft | website = www.faa.gov | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> to the end of allowing commercial drone operation,<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2016/2/25/11112864/faa-city-drone-flight-standards-task-force-amazon-google | title = FAA begins exploring how to allow drone flights over crowded cities | website = The Verge | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref> in response to requests from companies involved in commercial drone development such as [[Amazon Prime Air|Amazon]] and [[X (company)#Project Wing|Google]].<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/16/10777144/delivery-drones-regulations-safety-faa-autonomous-flight | title = What's really standing in the way of drone delivery? | website = The Verge | access-date = 2016-02-27 }}</ref>
On May 19, 2017, the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in ruling on Taylor v. Huerta <ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.recode.net/2017/5/19/15663436/us-drone-registration-rules-faa | title = Taylor v. Huerta | access-date = 2017-12-12 }}</ref> reversed the Dec. 2015 UAV registration rule, commenting that "the FAA may not promulgate any rule or regulation regarding a model aircraft." Specifically, the FAA’s Registration Rule for model aircraft (a/k/a drones) violates Section 336 of the FAA Modernization and Reform Act, and the FAA's Registration Rule to the extent it applied to model aircraft was vacated. The FAA began the process of refunding the registration fees.
On December 12, 2017, President Donald Trump signed into law the immediately-effective National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018, reinstating the FAA’s drone registration requirement. <ref>{{Cite web |url= https://techcrunch.com/2017/12/12/trump-signs-bill-reinstating-the-faas-drone-registration-requirement/ |title= Trump signs bill reinstating the FAA’s drone registration requirement |access-date= 2017-12-12 }}</ref>
==State-level regulation== Under 49 U.S. Code § 40103, "The United States Government has exclusive sovereignty of airspace of the United States" and U.S. citizens have "a public right of transit through the navigable airspace."<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/49/40103 49 U.S. Code § 40103]</ref> The FAA is invested with the authority to control traffic in navigable airspace and create operational and safety regulations on aircraft in navigable airspace. According to the FAA, "[a] navigable airspace free from inconsistent state and local restrictions is essential to the maintenance of a safe and sound air transportation system."<ref name="FAA: State-Local law fact sheet"/>{{Rp|2}} With respect to navigable airspace and the aircraft operating in that airspace, federal regulations have [[field preemption|preempted the field]] and the ability of state and local laws to regulate use of UAVs is limited.<ref name="FAA: State-Local law fact sheet">{{cite web|title=State and Local Regulation of Unmanned Aircraft System s (UAS) Fact Sheet|url=https://www.faa.gov/uas/regulations_policies/media/UAS_Fact_Sheet_Final.pdf|publisher=Federal Aviation Administration, Office of the Chief Counsel|accessdate=4 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203171552/http://www.faa.gov/uas/regulations_policies/media/UAS_Fact_Sheet_Final.pdf|archivedate=February 3, 2016|format=PDF|date=December 17, 2015|dead-url=no}}</ref>{{Rp|2–3}}
Examples of state and local laws that, according to the FAA, conflict with the FAA's federal legal authority and require consultation with the FAA before being enacted:<ref name="FAA: State-Local law fact sheet"/>{{Rp|3}} *Operational UAS restrictions on flight altitude, flight paths; operational bans; any regulation of the navigable airspace. For example–a city ordinance banning anyone from operating UAS within the city limits, within the air space of the city, or within certain distances of landmarks. *Mandating equipment or training for UAS related to aviation safety such as geo-fencing would likely be preempted. Courts have found that state regulation pertaining to mandatory training and equipment requirements related to aviation safety is not consistent with the federal regulatory framework. ''Med-Trans Corp. v. Benton'', 581 F. Supp. 2d 721, 740 (E.D.N.C. 2008); ''Air Evac EMS, Inc. v. Robinson'', 486 F. Supp. 2d 713, 722 (M.D. Tenn. 2007).
Examples of state and local laws that, according to the FAA, are generally permissible under the state's police powers:<ref name="FAA: State-Local law fact sheet"/>{{Rp|3}} *Requirement for police to obtain a warrant prior to using a UAS for surveillance. *Specifying that UAS may not be used for voyeurism. *Prohibitions on using UAS for hunting or fishing, or to interfere with or harass an individual who is hunting or fishing. *Prohibitions on attaching firearms or similar weapons to UAS.
In 2014, the California State Senate passed rules imposing strict regulations on how law enforcement and other government agencies can use drones. The legislation would require law enforcement agencies to obtain a warrant before using an unmanned aircraft, or drone, except in emergencies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Segar|first1=Mike|title=California Senate approves measure banning warrantless drone surveillance|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/28/us-usa-religion-minnesota-idUSKBN0GS03R20140828|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=11 September 2014}}</ref> In 2015, Virginia passed legislation that a drone may only be used in law enforcement if a warrant has been issued; excluding emergencies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Virginia HB 2125|url=https://leg1.state.va.us/cgi-bin/legp504.exe?151+cab+HC10226HB2125+HBSA}}</ref> New Jersey's drone legislation passed in 2015 states that not only are you required to provide a warrant for drone use in law enforcement, but the information collected must be disposed within two weeks.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Jersey A1039|url=https://leg1.state.va.us/cgi-bin/legp504.exe?151+ful+HB2125+pdf}}</ref> Other states that have drone regulation are Florida, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Montana, Oregon, Tennessee, Texas, and Wisconsin.<ref>{{cite web|title=Drone Privacy Bill|url=https://www.aclu.org/news/aclu-nj-cheers-passage-drone-privacy-bill-assembly-urges-senate-follow-suit-yes-vote}}</ref>
The first landmark court case on state and municipal drone regulation was ''Singer v. City of Newton'', No. 17-10071-WGY (D. Mass. Sept. 21, 2017). Dr. Michael Singer, a physician, technology advocate, and FAA-certificated drone operator, sued the City of [[Newton, Massachusetts]] challenging four provisions in the city's recently enacted drone ordinance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/johngoglia/2017/09/21/federal-judge-overturns-city-drone-ordinance-in-first-ruling-of-its-kind/#770282891217|title=Federal Judge Overturns City Drone Ordinance In First Ruling Of Its Kind|last=Goglia|first=John|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en}}</ref>'' '' These provisions required drone operators to register with the Newton city clerk; prohibited drone flights over the city without prior permission of all landowners below; and prohibited beyond-visual-line-of-sight (BVLOS) operations.<ref>{{Bluebook journal |first=|last=Note| title=Recent Case: Massachusetts District Court Finds Portion of Local Drone Ordinance Preempted by FAA Regulation | volume=131 | journal=[[Harvard Law Review|Harv. L. Rev.]] | page=2057 | url=https://harvardlawreview.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/2057-2064_Online.pdf| year=2018}}.</ref> Singer, who represented himself in court, argued that these provisions were preempted by the FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 and the Federal Aviation Act of 1958 (as recodified). U.S. District Judge [[William G. Young]] agreed, striking down the challenged parts of the ordinance due to [[Federal preemption#Conflict preemption|conflict preemption]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/judge-affirms-limited-power-of-states-and-cities-over-drones-1506123161|title=Judge Affirms Limited Power of States and Cities Over Drones|last=Gershman|first=Jacob|date=2017-09-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-01-01|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref><ref>{{cite court |litigants=Singer v. City of Newton |vol=284 |reporter=F. Supp. 3d |opinion=125 |court=D. Mass. |date=Sept. 21, 2017|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7213100011129767991|accessdate=}}</ref> The City of Newton appealed the decision to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit]], but later withdrew its appeal. ''Singer v. Newton'' is widely regarded as the first court case to examine the intersection of federal and state powers over drone operations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dlapiper.com/en/us/insights/publications/2017/09/federal-law-preempts-local-drone-ordinance/|title=Federal court finds that federal law preempts local drone ordinance {{!}} Insights {{!}} DLA Piper Global Law Firm|website=DLA Piper|access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref>
==Anti-UAV legislation== <!--Note: [[Austin Haughwout]] redirects here.--> Some locations, such as [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], [[Iowa City, Iowa]] and [[St. Bonifacius, Minnesota]] have passed legislation that limits use of UAVs.<ref name=usnews-charlotte-anti-drone-legislation>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2013/02/05/city-in-virginia-becomes-first-to-pass-anti-drone-legislation-|title=City in Virginia Becomes First to Pass Anti-Drone Legislation|last=Koebler|first=Jason|publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|date=5 February 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref><ref name=whotv-uncommon-ordinance>{{cite news|url=http://whotv.com/2013/06/19/no-drones-iowa-city-passes-uncommon-ordinance/|title=NO DRONES: Iowa City Passes Uncommon Ordinance|publisher=[[WHO-DT]]|date=19 June 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/west/201723501.html|title=St. Bonifacius says no to drones|publisher=[[Star Tribune]]|date=6 April 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013|last=Meersman|first=Tom}}</ref> In [[New York (state)|New York]] state, the city of [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] considered declaring the city a "Warrantless Surveillance Drone Free Zone" but put the legislation on hold after city counsellors became aware of a memorandum of understanding between the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] and the [[Federal Aviation Administration]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=954008#.UpzKQmSG0qQ|title=Drone free zone put on hold in Syracuse|last=Kenyon|first=Jim|publisher=[[WTVH]]|date=2 October 2013|accessdate=3 December 2013}}</ref>
In 2016, the [[Connecticut House of Representatives]] considered legislation to impose restrictions on drone weaponization. The legislation came after a man named Austin Haughwout, then an engineering student at [[Central Connecticut State University]] (CCSU), posted a video on YouTube showing a drone carrying a [[semi-automatic handgun]], which he had assembled, and which was seen to fire the gun several times.<ref name=guardian-gun-drone>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jul/21/drone-handgun-video-teen-connecticut|title=Teen's video of handgun-toting drone prompts federal investigation|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=21 Jul 2015|authors=Associated Press}}</ref><ref name=cnsnews-gun-drone>{{cite news|url=http://cnsnews.com/news/article/teenagers-video-gun-firing-drone-spurs-investigation|title=Teenager's video of gun-firing drone spurs investigation|authors=Associated Press|date=21 Jul 2015|publisher=[[Cybercast News Service]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jul/21/flying-gun-drone-investigated-faa-after-engineerin/|title=‘Flying Gun’ drone investigated by FAA after student’s YouTube video goes viral|last=Ernst|first=Douglas|date=21 Jul 2015|publisher=[[The Washington Times]]}}</ref>
==Prosecutions== In 2013, a UAV flying over [[Manhattan]] collided with several buildings and crashed onto the pavement.<ref name=wabc-helicopter-drone-crash>{{cite news|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news%2Finvestigators&id=9270668|title=EXCLUSIVE: Small drone crash lands in Manhattan|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Hoffer|first=Jim|date=3 October 2013|accessdate=5 October 2013}}</ref> It was reported that a man had been arrested days after the incident and that he had been charged with reckless endangerment.<ref name=wabc-helicopter-drone-arrest>{{cite news|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/investigators&id=9292217|title=EXCLUSIVE: Brooklyn man arrested for flying drone over Manhattan|publisher=[[ABC News]]|last=Hoffer|first=Jim|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref> He was identified because he was seen in the video recorded by the drone.<ref name=wabc-helicopter-drone-arrest/> The Federal Aviation Administration fined the man $2,200.<ref name=bloomberg-drone-operator-fined-after-almost-hitting-nyc-pedestrian>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-05-02/drone-operator-fined-after-almost-hitting-nyc-pedestrian.html|title=Drone Operator Fined After Almost Hitting NYC Pedestrian|publisher=[[bloomberg.com]]|last=Levin|first=Alan|date=3 May 2014|accessdate=5 May 2014}}</ref> The FAA said that his operation of the UAV was "flying in restricted airspace without getting permission from controllers and flying in a "careless or reckless manner" and "endangered the safety of the national airspace system".<ref name=bloomberg-drone-operator-fined-after-almost-hitting-nyc-pedestrian/> This was the first FAA attempt to penalise a non-commercial flight.<ref name=bloomberg-drone-operator-fined-after-almost-hitting-nyc-pedestrian/>
In 2015, a drone operated by a civilian flew into the White House property. As a result, the drone manufacturer, DJI, issued a statement saying that they will now require that all of their drones would contain built-in geofencing limits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Civilian Drone Use|url=https://www.aclu.org/blog/free-future/building-regulation-drones}}</ref>
==Lobbying== "Movie makers, real-estate agents, criminal-defense lawyers and farmers are among at least 68 groups with a newfound political interest in drones according to Center for Responsive Politics data compiled by Bloomberg".<ref name=bloomberg>{{cite news|last=Levin|first=Alan|title=Filmmakers to Farmers Seeking Drone Bonanza in Washington|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2014-05-12/filmmakers-to-farmers-seeking-drone-bonanza-by-influencing-d-dot-c|accessdate=May 17, 2014|newspaper=Bloomberg BNUsinessweek|date=May 12, 2014|author2=Laura LItvan}}</ref> At least 28 universities and local government agencies as well as Amazon hope to use drones civilly someday. Limited commercial operations for drones weighing less than 55 pounds (25 kilograms) is a proposal due to be decided upon by the end of the year.
In June 2014, the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] stated its support of an FAA exemption for the use of small drones in limited low risk scenarios in film and television productions.<ref name="2014HR-FAA">{{cite news|last1=Giardina|first1=Carolyn|title=FAA to Consider Hollywood Request for Exemption to Use Drones for Filming|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/faa-consider-hollywood-request-exemption-708703|accessdate=June 9, 2014|publisher=Hollywood Reporter|date=June 2, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.faa.gov/about/initiatives/uas/reg/ FAA UAS Regulations and Policies] * [http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/commercial-drones-a-dogfight-at-the-faa-02092012.html Commercial Drones: A Dogfight at the FAA; The aviation agency prepares for a deluge of unmanned aircraft in U.S. skies], 9 February 2012
[[Category:Aviation in the United States]] [[Category:Regulation of unmanned aerial vehicles|United States]] [[Category:United States regulations]]

'''Resistor–transistor logic''' ('''RTL''') (sometimes also '''transistor–resistor logic''' ('''TRL''')) is a class of [[digital circuit]]s built using [[resistor]]s as the input network and [[bipolar junction transistor]]s (BJTs) as switching devices. RTL is the earliest class of transistorized digital logic circuit used; other classes include [[diode–transistor logic]] (DTL) and [[transistor–transistor logic]] (TTL). RTL circuits were first constructed with [[discrete component]]s, but in 1961 it became the first digital [[logic family]] to be produced as a [[monolithic integrated circuit]]. RTL integrated circuits were used in the [[Apollo Guidance Computer]], whose design was begun in 1961 and which first flew in 1966.<ref>https://history.nasa.gov/computers/Ch2-5.html</ref>
== Implementation ==
=== RTL inverter ===
A bipolar [[Transistor#Transistor as a switch|transistor switch]] is the simplest RTL gate ([[Inverter (logic gate)|inverter]] or NOT gate) implementing [[logical negation]].<ref>[http://www.play-hookey.com/digital_electronics/rtl_gates.html Resistor-Transistor Logic] explains the basic RTL gates and gives some useful calculations</ref> It consists of a [[Common emitter|common-emitter stage]] with a base resistor connected between the base and the input voltage source. The role of the base resistor is to expand the very small transistor input voltage range (about 0.7 V) to the logical "1" level (about 3.5 V) by converting the input voltage into current. Its resistance is settled by a compromise: it is chosen low enough to saturate the transistor and high enough to obtain high input resistance. The role of the collector resistor is to convert the collector current into voltage; its resistance is chosen high enough to saturate the transistor and low enough to obtain low output resistance (high [[fan-out]]).
[[File:RTL NPN NOR Gate.svg|right|thumb|200px|Schematic of a one-transistor RTL NOR gate.]]
=== One-transistor RTL NOR gate ===
With two or more base resistors (R<sub>3</sub> and R<sub>4</sub>) instead of one, the inverter becomes a two-input RTL [[NOR gate]] (see the figure on the right). The logical operation [[Logical disjunction|OR]] is performed by applying consecutively the two arithmetic operations [[addition]] and [[Comparison (mathematics)|comparison]] (the input resistor network acts as a parallel ''voltage summer'' with equally weighted inputs and the following common-emitter transistor stage as a ''voltage comparator'' with a threshold about 0.7 V). The equivalent resistance of all the resistors connected to logical "1" and the equivalent resistance of all the resistors connected to logical "0" form the two legs of a composed voltage divider driving the transistor. The base resistances and the number of the inputs are chosen (limited) so that only one logical "1" is sufficient to create base-emitter voltage exceeding the threshold and, as a result, saturating the transistor. If all the input voltages are low (logical "0"), the transistor is cut-off. The [[pull-down resistor]] R<sub>1</sub> biases the transistor to the appropriate on-off threshold. The output is inverted since the collector-emitter voltage of transistor Q<sub>1</sub> is taken as output, and is high when the inputs are low. Thus, the analog resistive network and the analog transistor stage perform the logic function NOR.<ref>{{cite book |last=IBM |id=Form 223-6889 |first=IBM |year=1960 |title=Transistor Component Circuits |publisher=IBM |url=http://ibm-1401.info/Form223-6889-TransistorComponentCircuits.pdf |series=Customer Engineering Manual of Instruction |accessdate=2010-01-04 |quote=The logical function is performed by the input resistor network and the invert function is accomplished by the common emitter transistor configuration... }}</ref>
[[File:RTL 3-Input NOR Gate.svg|right|thumb|300px|Schematic of a multi-transistor RTL NOR gate used to build the [[Apollo Guidance Computer]]<ref name=AGC2005011> [[Apollo Guidance Computer]] schematics, [http://klabs.org/history/ech/agc_schematics/logic/5011-1.jpg Dwg. No. 2005011]. </ref>]] [[File:Agc nor2.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Photograph of the dual NOR gate chip used to build the [[Apollo Guidance Computer]] ]] [[File:Agc flatp.jpg|thumb|right|[[Flatpack (electronics)|Flatpack]] RTL NOR gate integrated circuits in the [[Apollo guidance computer]] ]]
=== Multi-transistor RTL NOR gate ===
The limitations of the one-transistor RTL NOR gate are overcome by the multi-transistor RTL implementation. It consists of a set of parallel-connected transistor switches driven by the logic inputs (see the figure on the right). In this configuration, the inputs are completely separated and the number of inputs is limited only by the small leakage current of the cut-off transistors at output logical "1". The same idea was used later for building [[Direct-coupled transistor logic|DCTL]], [[Emitter-coupled logic|ECL]], some [[Transistor-transistor logic|TTL]] (7450, 7460), [[NMOS logic|NMOS]] and [[CMOS]] gates.
== Advantages ==
The primary advantage of RTL technology was that it used a minimum number of transistors. In circuits using discrete components, before integrated circuits, transistors were the most expensive component to produce. Early IC logic production (such as Fairchild's in 1961) used the same approach briefly, but quickly transitioned to higher-performance circuits such as [[diode–transistor logic]] and then [[transistor–transistor logic]] (starting 1963 at Sylvania), since diodes and transistors were no more expensive than resistors in the IC.<ref>{{cite book | title = Electronics: The Life Story of a Technology | author = David L. Morton Jr. and Joseph Gabriel | publisher = JHU Press | year = 2007 | isbn = 0-8018-8773-9 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=rABggQmp31MC&pg=PA84&dq=rtl+dtl+ttl+integrated+circuits }}</ref>
== Limitations ==
The disadvantage of RTL is its high power dissipation when the transistor is switched on, by current flowing in the collector and base resistors. This requires that more current be supplied to and heat be removed from RTL circuits. In contrast, TTL circuits with "[[Totem pole output|totem-pole]]" output stage minimize both of these requirements.
Another limitation of RTL is its limited [[fan-in]]: 3 inputs being the limit for many circuit designs, before it completely loses usable noise immunity.{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} It has a low [[noise margin]]. Lancaster says that integrated circuit RTL NOR gates (which have one transistor per input) may be constructed with "any reasonable number" of logic inputs, and gives an example of an 8-input NOR gate.<ref name=Lancaster> {{cite book |author=Donald E. Lancaster |title=RTL cookbook |year= 1969 |isbn=0-672-20715-X |publisher=Bobbs-Merrill Co. (or Howard W Sams) |url=http://www.alibris.com/booksearch?qsort=p&siteID=BMAI54k.xMY-6bJvSC2hb2j9kKSb5V.rLA&qtit=RTL+Cookbook}} </ref>
A standard integrated circuit RTL NOR [[Logic gate|gate]] can drive up to 3 other similar gates. Alternatively, it has enough output to drive up to 2 standard integrated circuit RTL "buffers", each of which can drive up to 25 other standard RTL NOR gates.<ref name=Lancaster/>
== Speeding up RTL ==
Various companies applied the following speed-up methods to discrete RTL.
Transistor switching speed has increased steadily from the first transistorized computers through the present. The ''GE Transistor Manual'' (7th ed., p. 181, or 3rd ed., p. 97 or intermediate editions) recommends gaining speed by using higher-frequency transistors, or capacitors, or a diode from base to collector ([[Baker clamp|parallel negative feedback]]) to prevent saturation.<ref name=Cleary> {{cite book | author = Cleary, J. F. (ed.) | title = ''GE Transistor Manual'' | edition = third through seventh editions | publisher = General Electric, Semiconductor Products Department, Syracuse, NY | year = 1958–1964 }} </ref>
Placing a capacitor in parallel with each input resistor decreases the time needed for a driving stage to forward-bias a driven stage's base-emitter junction. Engineers and technicians use "RCTL" (resistor capacitor transistor logic) to designate gates equipped with "speed-up capacitors". The Lincoln Laboratory [[TX-0|TX-0 computer's]] circuits included some RCTL.<ref name=Fadiman> {{cite book | last=Fadiman | first=J. R. | year=1956 | title=TX0 Computer Circuitry | publisher = MIT Lincoln Laboratory | url=http://bitsavers.org/pdf/ibm/140x/1401_CE_Drws_1962.pdf | accessdate=2011-09-09 }} </ref> However, methods involving capacitors were unsuitable for integrated circuits.{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}
Using a high collector supply voltage and diode clamping decreased collector-base and wiring capacitance charging time. This arrangement required diode clamping the collector to the design logic level. This method was also applied to discrete DTL ([[diode–transistor logic]]).<ref name=DEC> {{cite book | last=DEC | first=Flip_Chip | year=1967 | title=The Digital Logic Handbook | publisher = Digital Equipment Corporation| url=http://www.bitsavers.org/pdf/dec/handbooks/ | accessdate=2008-03-08 }} </ref>
Another method that was familiar in [[discrete-device]] logic circuits used a diode and a resistor, a germanium and a silicon diode, or three diodes in a negative feedback arrangement. These diode networks known as various [[Baker clamp]]s reduced the voltage applied to the base as the collector approached saturation. Because the transistor went less deeply into saturation, the transistor accumulated fewer stored charge carriers. Therefore, less time was required to clear stored charge during transistor turn off.<ref name=Cleary/> A low-voltage diode arranged to prevent saturation of the transistor was applied to integrated logic families by using [[Schottky diode]]s, as in Schottky [[Transistor–transistor logic|TTL]].
==See also== * [[NORBIT]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{cite web |title=What Computers Are Made From |author-first=John J. G. |author-last=Savard |date=2018 |orig-year=2005 |work=quadibloc |url=http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/cp01.htm |access-date=2018-07-16 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180702235616/http://www.quadibloc.com/comp/cp01.htm |archive-date=2018-07-02}}

revision.text:
The '''SATURN Development Group''' was an important [[industry forum]] that enabled the specification of [[chip-to-chip interface]]s for the communications industry. It was co-founded in 1992 by [[PMC-Sierra]] and [[Sun Microsystems]]. Several significant specifications were completed through its actions including PL-2, [[PL-3]], and [[PL-4]]. Many important semiconductor devices were developed to these specifications. SATURN was also influential in the specification of the [[ATM Forum]]'s physical layer "UTOPIA" standards.
Initial members included [[SynOptics]] and [[Interphase]]. The first meeting was held in April 1992. By August 1993, the SATURN group had 28 members.
After the formation of the [[Optical Internetworking Forum]] (OIF), two of the SATURN group's interfaces were successfully adopted by OIF. The [[PL-3]] specification became [[SPI-3]] and the [[PL-4]] specification became [[SPI-4.2]]. The existence of the OIF also eliminated the need for the SATURN Development Group, and it was wound down around 2002.
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20001218094200/http://www.cs-ipv6.lancs.ac.uk/ipv6/mail-archive/Cell-Relay/1993-09/0041.html Early history of SATURN] * [http://www.lightreading.com/document.asp?doc_id=4561&site=lightreading Light Reading article on PL-4] * [http://www.lightreading.com/document.asp?site=lightreading&doc_id=4849&page_number=8 Light Reading article on PL-5]

revision.text:
{{redir|saw doctor|the band|The Saw Doctors}} {{Unreferenced|date=March 2014}} A '''saw filer''' or '''saw doctor''' is a person who maintains and repairs saws in a [[saw mill]]. A saw filer's work area in the mill is called the '''filing room'''.
Saws used in timber mills are very large and expensive. They need careful [[Maintenance, repair, and operations|maintenance]] for safe operation. Repair of damaged saws requires a high degree of skill. It takes many years of full-time saw filing to become proficient in the trade.
== Bandsaw filing == [[Bandsaw]]s in timber mills range in size from about (4" x 22ga x 10') to (16" x 11ga x 62') and can use any of the three main different saw band types: *Single-cut saws have, as the name implies, teeth on one side, allowing for cutting in one direction only. *Double-cut saws have teeth on both sides. These types are designed for machinery that allows the log or work piece to be cut from either the front or the back direction of travel. *"Sliver tooth" saws have teeth on both sides but they have different profiles. The (usual) front side have teeth with a regular style tooth. The back of these saws have a longer style. The log is cut in a forward direction as with a single-cut but as the log returns, the saw de-burrs the ''cut'' (path where the saw passes) allowing for a cleaner finish. They are run for 4 to 24 hours then sent to the saw filer for maintenance.
The saw filer inspects the saw for needed repairs then gums, fits and benches the saw as necessary.
'''Gumming''' involves grinding the gullets of the saw teeth to a particular shape. The saw filer uses a semi or fully automatic [[grinding machine]] for this. Saw bands operate under high stress and heat and in the presence of wood chips. Carbon migrates into the steel from the wood. Gumming prevents [[case hardening]] and fatigue cracking of the saw band gullets. Resaw Bandsaws (teeth on one side only) may be left or right-handed, depending on which way the teeth are pointing and which way the plank falls from the log when cutting. Double cut saws (teeth on both sides) are always gummed right hand teeth first.
A precise profile of the tooth (including gullet area, hook angle and top clearance angle) must be maintained for proper saw operation and wood chip removal. Ease of cutting greatly depends on this. The shape is determined by the type of wood and cutting conditions. A saw filer will maintain the gullet shape by manually shaping the grinding wheel with a dressing stone, and the set up of his grinding machine. Variations include face angle, face length, back angle, gullet width and depth, and a frost notch (if necessary). Typical bandsaw tooth dimensions are 1-3/4" tooth space x 3/4" gullet depth x 3/4" gullet width (grinding wheel width) x 30deg face angle x 16deg back angle.
'''Fitting''' means tooth dressing and involves swaging, shaping, gauging, and grinding. The tip of the saw tooth is [[swaging|swaged]] to a flare, then the sides are compressed in slightly with a shaper tool to an exact [[wikt:kerf|kerf]]. Then a final grinding pass is made. The usual gauged tolerance is +/- .005" in kerf, and < .003" side to side variation. The same grinding machinery used for gumming is used for fitting.
The saw kerf is usually made this way from the base saw metal. Sometimes, however, the kerf is made with [[stellite]] or [[Tungsten carbide|carbide]] tips, in which case swaging and shaping isn't needed, although gumming is still required. The kerf may also be 'set' with a punch and hammer, with the teeth bent left, right, left... Set teeth are rarely used.
'''Benching''' is the leveling and tensioning of the saw. When a saw band is run on a mill it is stretched with thousands of pounds of force, and during operation the cutting edge heats up. These forces and temperatures cause the saw to deform. Benching deforms an un-mounted saw in a way that counteracts the operating stresses, and allows the saw to pull flat and cut straight when in use. It takes months to learn benching.
Benching is done in a dark room with a stretcher-roller machine and flat anvil. A single light at the benchman’s work station, along with ground gauges, allows the saw filer to measure level and tension.
Leveling is done with a crossface hammer and stretcher-roller adjustments. Cross face hammers are available in left and right hand versions. Each filer has his own hammer which he carefully dresses.
Tensioning is done with the stretcher-roll. This machine has hardened rollers above and below the saw. They rotate slowly (one is powered, while one runs free) and pinch the saw when a lever is cranked, rolling a thin strip through the length of the saw, stretching the metal where it was rolled. Careful placement and force of the rolls deform the metal in a way that counteracts the forces the saw sees during operation. More rolls are placed in the midsection of the saw. Resaws have the back pulled to counteract the uneven heating of the cutting edge. This is done by rolling the back (non cutting edge) of the saw. The back is measured with a three pin gauge, and is usually around .003" per three feet curved.
Benching involves the simultaneous solution of multiple deformations introduced to the saw to counteract the predicted stresses of the saw in operation. Benchman can easily recognize variations in steel batches.
Other bandsaw duties include [[welding]] broken teeth, fixing cracks, and [[trouble shooting]] operating problems.
[[CNC]] equipment has evolved to the point of being able to do significant benching and fitting tasks.
Most of the above terms are North American and are called different things in Australia, New Zealand as well as else where in the world. A Sawdoctor does both the tasks of the Benchman and Filler at the same time, with no distinction between the tasks as well as having to do both circular saws and bandsaws. This like filing rooms are called Saw Shops in Australia. Most Saw Mills in Australia and New Zealand run a stellite tipped bandsaw in which the majority of what is stated above becomes redundant as it is specifically for sharpening and making the swaged tipped saws.
==Circular saw benching==<!-- This section is linked from [[Circular saw]] --> Saw filers have the same maintenance duties with circular saws as they do with band saws, with a few exceptions; *leveling is done mostly with specialized hammers of which there are 3 main types Dog head(side on profile resembles a dogs snout), twist face (A double sided hammer in which the faces are in a 45 degree alignment) and cross face ( faces are at 90 degrees to one another) and anvils (there are 2 main type of anvils dead (for levelling the saw) and live(for both leveling and tensioning the saw), although stretcher-roller machines are also used for leveling and tensioning. *Circular saws can be solid tooth(straight saw steel which are bent to give clearance of the saw blade) or can have carbide, Stellite or insert teeth that don't need swaging. *Fatigue cracking of the tooth gullet is not as common as in band saws, as in the majority of cases it is a heavier plate gauge and is not bent around band wheels multiple thousands of times per run.
==See also== *[[Bandsaw]] *[[Circular saw]] *[[Saw mill]] *[[Saw]] *[[Portable sawmill]]
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Simulate Loam Substrate<ref>[http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTotal-ZGDH201801022.htm “Simulate loam”spray sowing technology and its application in restoration and management of mine environment''].[[China National Knowledge Infrastructure]]''.Retrieved 15 January 2018.</ref><ref>[http://www.lvyan.cn/about/?192.html Jiangsu Lvyan：Mine geological environment restorer].''lvyan.cn''.Retrieved 8 October 2018.</ref>''', or '''mechanism-based Loam Substrate'''<ref>[https://patents.google.com/patent/CN206815352U/en CN206815352U - Side slope mechanism of class loam matrix''].[[Google Patents]]''.Retrieved 16 May 2017.</ref>({{zh|类壤土基质}}<ref>[http://news.sina.com.cn/o/2018-06-25/doc-iheirxyf4487151.shtml 有色金屬礦產地質調查中心攜手江蘇綠岩生態技術股份有限公司共同打造綠色治理技術體系].''[[sina.com]]''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 28 June 2018.</ref><ref>[http://www.mlr.gov.cn/xwdt/jrxw/201806/t20180625_1939177.htm China Nonferrous Metals Resource Geological Survey intends to build a green governance technology system''[[Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China]]''].(in Chinese).Retrieved 25 June 2018.</ref><ref>[http://epub.sipo.gov.cn/tdcdesc.action?strWhere=CN206815352U 2017205412990 一種类壤土基质的邊坡機構].''[[National Intellectual Property Administration]]''.Retrieved 29 December 2017.</ref>) is an ecological environment [[green governance]] technology, <ref>[http://www.mlr.gov.cn/xwdt/kyxw/201712/t20171219_1710145.htm Simulate Loam Substrate creates landscapes on bald slope''[[Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China]]''].(in Chinese).Retrieved 19 December 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.gdlr.gov.cn/gdsgtzyt/xydt/xydt59/1917864/index.html The Research Center for Ecological Environment Green Governance was formally established].''Department of Land and Resources of Guangdong Province''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 12 March 2018.</ref>based upon the [[concept]] of restoring [[Nature]] in a natural way, <ref>[http://www.mlr.gov.cn/xwdt/jrxw/201803/t20180312_1763342.htm 聚焦生態環境綠色治理研究中心掛牌].''[[Ministry of Land and Resources of the People's Republic of China]]''.Retrieved 12 March 2018.</ref><ref>[http://zjg.js.xinhuanet.com/2018-04/19/c_1122708770.htm 生態環境綠色治理研究中心授牌].''[[Xinhuanet]]''.Retrieved 19 April 2018.</ref><ref>[http://www.zjgonline.com.cn/index.php?option=com_content&id=65055 Zhangjiagang Lvyan Ecological Technology: Restoring nature in a natural way].''zjgonline.com''.Retrieved 11 May 2018.</ref>developed and put into operation by [[Zhang Bo (entrepreneur)|Zhang Bo]],<ref>[http://www.zfxxgk.suzhou.gov.cn/sxqzf/szsrmzf/201801/P020180129361485690184.pdf Suzhou Municipal People's Government Document: Decision of the Municipal Government on Issuing the 2017 Suzhou Science and Technology Awards].''suzhou.gov.cn''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 10 March 2018.</ref> [[general manager]] of Jiangsu Lvyan Ecological Technology Co., Ltd.<ref>[http://xinsanban.eastmoney.com/Article/NoticeContent?id=AN201508310010676268 Jiangsu Lvyan Ecological Technology Co., Ltd.:Public Transfer Instructions].''[[Eastmoney.com]]''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 31 August 2015.</ref><ref>[http://xinsanban.eastmoney.com/Article/NoticeContent?id=AN201508310010676313 Jiangsu Lvyan Ecological Technology :additional legal submission].''[[Eastmoney.com]]''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 45 January 2016.</ref><ref>[http://www.neeq.com.cn/disclosure/2016/2016-04-14/1460629863_271196.pdf 江蘇綠岩生態技術股份有限公司關於補充確認2015年度關聯交易的公告]''[[National Equities Exchange and Quotations]]''.Retrieved 14 April 2016.</ref><ref>[http://gtszb.gtzyb.com/gtszb/resfile/2015-01-24/01/01.pdf 甘肅國土資源工作受到省委高度重視].''China Land and Resources News''.Retrieved 24 January 2015.</ref>
==Technical Overview== ===Technical Concept=== Restore [[Nature]] in a Natural way is the technical concept of ''Simulate Loam Substrate'', and this technology is applied to form the ideal [[soil structure]], select suitable plant species to ensure the proportion of [[tree]]s and [[shrub]]s in the later plant communities, <ref name="National Intellectual Property Administration">[http://epub.sipo.gov.cn/tdcdesc.action?strWhere=CN107251729A 2017103443306 A Simulate Loam Substrate spray-casting construction method for slope].''[[National Intellectual Property Administration]]''.Retrieved 17 October 2017.</ref>so as to restore [[Nature]].<ref>[http://lvyan.cn/about/?192.html Simulate Loam Substrate：Mine geological environment recovery technology].''lvyan.cn''.(in Chinese and English).Retrieved 12 September 2018.</ref><ref name="China Land and Resources News">[http://zgdzzhyfz.paperopen.com/oa/darticle.aspx?type=view&id=180123 类壤土基质技術及其在礦山環境恢復治理中的若干應用].''China Land and Resources News''.(in Chinese and English).Retrieved 25 February 2018.</ref><ref>[http://www.cnki.com.cn/Article/CJFDTotal-ZGDH201801022.htm Simulate Loam Substrate类壤土基质及相關應用].''[[China National Knowledge Infrastructure]]''.Retrieved 22 January 2018.</ref> ===Technical principle=== As the ecological environment green governance technology, the core of ''Simulate Loam Substrate'' is to combine the engineering, botany, soil science and other disciplines to simulate the loam matrix structure suitable for plant growth through [[biomimetic technology]], which is beneficial to plant seeds, root development, microbial activity and nutrient transformation.<ref name="National Intellectual Property Administration"/><ref>[http://lib.cqu.edu.cn/asset/detail.aspx?id=203282775542 类壤土基质：一種新型生態環境綠色治理技術].''[[Chongqing University]]''.Retrieved 9 August 2017.</ref>
==Functions<ref name="Simulate Loam Substrate">[http://www.cqvip.com/qk/98314x/201801/674820898.html “Simulate Loam Substrate” technology and its application in mine environmental restoration and treatment].''cqvip.com''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 19 January 2018.</ref>== Simulate Loam Substrate can remold soil layer structure, <ref>[http://www.zrzyb.net/dizhikuangchan/20171027_108067.shtml 有色地勘行業達成共識 民生地質發展前景廣闊].''China Land and Resources News''.(in Chinese).Retrieved 27 October 2017.</ref> resist erosion and control the growth ratio of [[tree]]s and [[shrub]]s.<ref>[http://cqvip.com/QK/98314X/201801/674820898.html Simulate Loam Substrate and its applications].''cqvip.com''..Retrieved 15 March 2018.</ref>
==Application Area<ref name="Simulate Loam Substrate"/>== Simulate Loam Substrate can be used in [[real estate]] development surrounding landscape mountain management, high and steep slope treatment of highway and railway and [[open pit]] [[slope]] environmental treatment.<ref>[http://www.zfxxgk.suzhou.gov.cn/sxqzf/szsrmzf/201801/t20180129_959097.html 市政府關於頒發2017年度蘇州市科學技術獎的決定].''zfxxgk.suzhou.gov.cn''..Retrieved 29 January 2018.</ref>
